gettingStarted.title: Getting Started
gettingStarted.basicUsageDescription: Bokuchi is a powerful Markdown editor with real-time preview. You can write Markdown content in the editor and see the rendered result instantly in the preview panel.
gettingStarted.newFileDescription: Create a new empty file to start writing.
gettingStarted.openFileDescription: Open an existing Markdown file from your computer.
gettingStarted.saveFileDescription: Save the current file to disk.
gettingStarted.splitViewDescription: Show editor and preview side by side for easy editing and reviewing.
gettingStarted.editorOnlyDescription: Focus on writing with only the editor visible.
gettingStarted.previewOnlyDescription: View the rendered result in full screen.

variables.title: Variables
variables.description: Variables allow you to use dynamic content in your Markdown files. You can define variables in the settings and reference them in your documents using {{variableName}} syntax.
variables.howToUseDescription: To use variables in your Markdown files, simply wrap the variable name in double curly braces. The variable will be replaced with its value when the document is rendered.
variables.settingUpDescription: Follow these steps to set up and use variables:
variables.step1Description: Click the menu button and select 'Settings' to open the settings dialog.
variables.step2Description: In the 'Global Variables' section, add variable names and their corresponding values.
variables.step3Description: Reference variables in your Markdown files using {{variableName}} syntax.

example1.title: Document Template
example1.description: Use variables for document metadata like title, date, and author.

example2.title: Company Template
example2.description: Use variables for company information like name, department, and version.

variables.tip1Description: Variable names cannot contain spaces. Use camelCase or snake_case for multi-word variables.
variables.tip2Description: Variable names are case-sensitive. Make sure to use the exact same case in your documents.
variables.tip3Description: Variables are global and can be used in all your documents. Changes to variables affect all open files.
variables.localVariablesDescription: You can also define variables within individual files using HTML comments. These local variables take precedence over global variables.
variables.localVariablesSyntaxDescription: Define local variables at the beginning of your Markdown file using the following syntax:
variables.localVariablesCodeExample:
<!-- @var title: My Document Title -->
<!-- @var author: John Doe -->
<!-- @var date: 2024-01-15 -->

# {{title}}

Author: {{author}}
Date: {{date}}
variables.priorityOrderDescription: When the same variable name exists in both local and global scope, the following priority order applies:
variables.localVsGlobalDescription: Use local variables for file-specific content and global variables for common content across multiple files.

tutorials.title: Quick Start Guide
tutorials.description: Get started with Bokuchi in just a few steps:

step1.title: Step 1: Create Your First Document
instructions: Press ⌘N (Mac) or Ctrl+N (Windows) to create a new file
Type your first heading: # My First Document
Add some content below the heading
Watch the preview update in real-time on the right

step2.title: Step 2: Save Your Work
instructions: Choose a location and filename for your document
Your file will appear in Recent Files for quick access

step3.title: Step 3: Use Variables for Dynamic Content
instructions: Add a variable like 'author' with your name
In your document, use {{author}} where you want your name to appear

step4.title: Step 4: Navigate Efficiently
instructions: Press ⌘R (Mac) or Ctrl+R (Windows) to open Recent Files
Use Ctrl+Tab to switch between open tabs
Use Ctrl+Shift+Tab to go to the previous tab

tips.title: Pro Tips
tips.tip1: Use F1 anytime to open this help system
tips.tip2: Try different themes in Settings > Appearance
tips.tip3: Use the split view to see your Markdown and preview side by side
